chat.content:
I will give you a Coq proof state, including both hypotheses and a specific goal and your need to prove it. Your response should be a singular code block of Coq proof, without any additional explanation or commentary. Follow to these guidelines:
Introduce variables using unique names to avoid any conflicts.
Keep each command distinct and separated, avoid concatenations like ';' or '[cmd|cmd]'.
Organize your proof with bullets like '-', '+', and '*' instead of braces ({, }). Shift to their double symbols like '--' and '++', when necessary.
Effectively use given premises, follow the syntax and structure demonstrated in the examples provided.

Example 1:

Hypotheses:
n, m: nat
IHn: m + n = n + m

Goal:
m + S n = S n + m

Proof:
```simpl. rewrite <- IHn. auto.```

Example 2:
Hypotheses:

Goal:
forall n m : nat, m + n = n + m

```intros n m. induction n.
- simpl. auto.
- simpl. rewrite <- IHn. auto.```

Sovle This Proof State:

Hypotheses:


Goal:
enumT nat

Record enumT (X : Type) : Type := Build_enumT { L_T : nat -> list X; cum_T : cumulative L_T; el_T : forall x : X, exists m : nat, x ∈ L_T m } Arguments enumT _%type_scope Arguments Build_enumT [X]%type_scope [L_T]%function_scope _ _%function_scope
Inductive nat : Set := O : nat | S : nat -> nat Arguments S _%nat_scope
L_T = fun (X : Type) (enumT0 : enumT X) => let (L_T, _, _) := enumT0 in L_T : forall X : Type, enumT X -> nat -> list X Arguments L_T {X}%type_scope {enumT} _%nat_scope, _ {enumT} _
cum_T = fun (X : Type) (enumT0 : enumT X) => let (L_T, cum_T, _) as enumT return (cumulative L_T) := enumT0 in cum_T : forall (X : Type) (enumT : enumT X), cumulative L_T Arguments cum_T {X}%type_scope {enumT}
Build_enumT : forall (X : Type) (L_T : nat -> list X), cumulative L_T -> (forall x : X, exists m : nat, x ∈ L_T m) -> enumT X
enum_bool = {| L_T := fun _ : nat => [true; false]; cum_T := fun _ : nat => ex_intro (fun A : list bool => [true; false] = true :: false :: A) [] eq_refl; el_T := fun b : bool => ex_intro (fun _ : nat => b ∈ [true; false]) 1 (if b as b0 return (b0 ∈ [true; false]) then or_introl eq_refl else or_intror (or_introl eq_refl)) |} : enumT bool

Nat.divide = fun x y : nat => exists z : nat, y = z * x : nat -> nat -> Prop Arguments Nat.divide (_ _)%nat_scope
seq = fix seq (start len : nat) {struct len} : list nat := match len with | 0 => [] | S len0 => start :: seq (S start) len0 end : nat -> nat -> list nat Arguments seq (_ _)%nat_scope

Nat.sqrt_up = fun a : nat => match 0 ?= a with | Lt => S (Nat.sqrt (Nat.pred a)) | _ => 0 end : nat -> nat Arguments Nat.sqrt_up _%nat_scope
Nat.Even = fun n : nat => exists m : nat, n = 2 * m : nat -> Prop Arguments Nat.Even _%nat_scope
BinIntDef.Z.of_nat = fun n : nat => match n with | 0 => BinNums.Z0 | S n0 => BinNums.Zpos (BinPos.Pos.of_succ_nat n0) end : nat -> BinNums.Z Arguments BinIntDef.Z.of_nat _%nat_scope
BinPosDef.Pos.testbit_nat = fix testbit_nat (p : BinNums.positive) : nat -> bool := match p with | BinNums.xI p0 => fun n : nat => match n with | 0 => true | S n' => testbit_nat p0 n' end | BinNums.xO p0 => fun n : nat => match n with | 0 => false | S n' => testbit_nat p0 n' end | BinNums.xH => fun n : nat => match n with | 0 => true | S _ => false end end : BinNums.positive -> nat -> bool Arguments BinPosDef.Pos.testbit_nat _%positive_scope _%nat_scope
Fin.to_nat = fix to_nat (m : nat) (n : Fin.t m) {struct n} : {i : nat | i < m} := match n in (Fin.t n0) return {i : nat | i < n0} with | @Fin.F1 j => exist (fun i : nat => i < S j) 0 (Nat.lt_0_succ j) | @Fin.FS n0 p => let (i, P) := to_nat n0 p in exist (fun i0 : nat => i0 < S n0) (S i) (lt_n_S i n0 P) end : forall m : nat, Fin.t m -> {i : nat | i < m} Arguments Fin.to_nat {m}%nat_scope

bet_emp : forall (P : nat -> Prop) (k : nat), between P k k
